modules.name: What is Social Engineering
modules.description: Understanding the basics of social engineering attacks and human psychology
modules.content:
What to Expect

Welcome to Module 1! We're starting with the most crucial concept: social engineering. Over the next two lessons, we will define what it is, why it works, and how it directly affects your life as a student.

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Define social engineering and explain why it's a human-based attack, not a technical one.
  • Recognize the psychological tricks that scammers use, such as Authority, Urgency, and Liking, to manipulate you.

Module 1: Social Engineering

Understanding the basics of social engineering attacks and human psychology

Lesson 1.1: Social Engineering

1. What is Social Engineering

Content will be added here...

This is where the actual lesson content will be placed.

2. Core Lesson Content: The Anatomy of a Human-Based Attack

Content will be added here...

This is where the actual lesson content will be placed.

3. Lesson Conclusion: What is Social Engineering?

Content will be added here...

This is where the actual lesson content will be placed.

Lesson 1.2: The Psychology Behind the Deception

1. What is Social Engineering

Content will be added here...

This is where the actual lesson content will be placed.

2. Core Lesson Content: The Anatomy of a Human-Based Attack

Content will be added here...

This is where the actual lesson content will be placed.

3. Lesson Conclusion: What is Social Engineering?

This is where the actual lesson content will be placed.

Reflection

Module 1 Reflection: "Could This Happen to Me?"

Welcome to your reflection for Module 1!

Now that you've completed this module, it's time to think about how social engineering shows up in your own life.

Reflection Prompts

  1. Think about a time when someone tried to get you to act quickly, trust them blindly, or give out personal information‚Äîonline or offline. What happened?
  2. Now that you've completed this module, do you think it might have been a social engineering attempt?
  3. How did you respond then, and how would you act differently now?
BONUS: Share one "aha moment" from this module

What surprised you the most about social engineering, and what habit or mindset will you change starting today?

Submit Your Reflection

Knowledge Check

Knowledge check questions will be added here...

This is where quiz questions and assessments will be placed.

References

References will be added here...

This is where source materials and citations will be placed.

questions.question_text: According to Lesson 1.1, which of the following is the most accurate definition of social engineering?
questions.option_a: The use of complex code to bypass a digital firewall.
questions.option_b: The practice of analyzing social media to improve network security.
questions.option_c: The art of manipulating people into giving up confidential information by exploiting psychological tricks.
questions.option_d: The process of building better, more secure computer hardware.
questions.explanation: Social engineering is 'human hacking' ‚Äî manipulating people using psychological tricks.

questions.question_text: What is the primary way social engineering differs from a traditional technical hack?
questions.option_a: Social engineering is only used for pranks, while technical hacking is for serious crimes.
questions.option_b: Social engineering targets the human user to bypass security, while technical hacking targets vulnerabilities in software or systems.
questions.option_c: Social engineering requires advanced programming skills, while technical hacking does not.
questions.option_d: Social engineering can only be done over the phone, not through email.
questions.explanation: Key difference: people vs. systems. Social engineering targets human behavior to bypass controls.

questions.question_text: You receive an email 'URGENT: Your Student Portal Password Will Expire in 24 Hours!' from the 'Registrar's Office' with a link. This attack primarily uses which two principles?
questions.explanation: Impersonating a trusted department (Authority) and forcing quick action (Urgency).

questions.question_text: Based on the examples in the lessons (Bitcoin scam, GCash requests), what is a common motivation for social engineers?
questions.option_a: To test a company's firewall for weaknesses.
questions.option_b: To make new friends and connections online.
questions.option_c: To gain access to information or resources for personal or financial benefit.
questions.option_d: To help users become more skeptical and informed.
questions.explanation: Attackers aim for valuable gain: money, access, or sensitive data.

questions.question_text: A pop-up says: "FREE 1000 GEMS! Limited to the first 500 players!" This tactic relies on the principle of:
questions.explanation: Creating fear of missing out (limited slots) is classic Scarcity.

modules.name: Phishing: The Digital Net
modules.description: Recognize, detect, and defend against phishing across email, SMS, and calls
modules.content:
What to Expect

Welcome to Module 2! In our last module, you learned that social engineering is all about human psychology. Now, it's time to put that knowledge into action. This module will give you the tools to identify common attack vectors like phishing, pretexting, and baiting, so you can spot a scam from a mile away.

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Spot the red flags of phishing emails, smishing texts, and vishing calls.
  • Differentiate between pretexting and baiting attacks.
  • Identify physical social engineering tactics like tailgating and shoulder surfing.

Module 2: Phishing

Recognize, detect, and defend against phishing across email, SMS, and calls

Lesson 2.1: Phishing

1. Phishing in Philippine

Welcome to Module 2! In our last lesson, you learned about the psychology behind social engineering. Now, we're going to dive into its most common and dangerous form: phishing. This video will show you why it's such a threat here in the Philippines and introduce you to your first toolkit for spotting scams

Email Phishing ‚Ä¢ Smishing ‚Ä¢ Vishing

Module 2 Lesson 2.1 Part A ‚Äî Phishing in the Philippines
2. The Anatomy of a Phishing Attack

The Anatomy of a Phishing Attack

What is Phishing?

Phishing is a cybercrime where an attacker pretends to be a trusted source‚Äîlike your bank, a favorite brand, or even your school‚Äîto trick you into revealing personal information. These attacks rely on deception, and they're a huge problem here in the Philippines.

üìä Local Impact

A 2025 report by Kaspersky found that our country logged over 38,000 phishing attempts last year alone (Kaspersky, 2025).

Types of Phishing Attacks

Phishing doesn't just happen through email. It comes in different forms:

Smishing (SMS-based Phishing)

This is a phishing attack delivered via text message. Scammers often use SMS to impersonate local banks or e-wallets, telling you that your account is blocked.

Vishing (Voice Phishing)

This involves a fraudulent phone call where a scammer pretends to be a bank employee to deceive you.

üì∞ Recent Local Case: A recent local case in Cavite saw nine scammers arrested for defrauding victims of up to ‚Ç±40 million using vishing tactics (PNP-ACG, 2024).

Spot the Red Flags

So, how can you spot a phishing attempt? Before you click any link or give out any information, check for these red flags:

Generic Greetings

Scammers often use impersonal greetings like "Dear Valued Customer" because they are sending the same message to thousands of people.

A Sense of Urgency

The message will try to pressure you into acting immediately with phrases like "Your account will be suspended if you don't click now!"

Suspicious Links and Email Addresses

Always check the full email address and the URL of a link. Scammers often use fake logos and website addresses with subtle typos (e.g., facebo0k.com instead of facebook.com).

Grammatical Errors

Many phishing messages contain misspellings or awkward phrasing.

Requests for Sensitive Information

Legitimate companies will never ask for your password, PIN, or One-Time Password (OTP) via email or text.

üõ°Ô∏è Your Best Defense

By remembering these red flags, you can become your own best defense against phishing scams.

"Spot the Phish"

You've learned that phishing is a digital trap that uses clever tricks to steal your information. This infographic is your quick reference guide to the key red flags to watch out for. Keep it handy to help you spot a scam in an instant.

üìß Mock Phishing Email

üì± Mock Phishing SMS

üí° Remember

You can download a checklist version of this guide to keep handy for quick reference. When in doubt, always pause, verify, and never click on a suspicious link. You've got this!

3. Conclusion: Smarter Than the Scam

üéâ Lesson 2.1 Conclusion: Smarter Than the Scam

üéØ Congratulations!

You've just completed our lesson on phishing. You've now built a critical skill that will help protect you and your community from the most common type of cyberattack.

Remember

Phishing doesn't break your computer‚Äîit tricks you. By learning to recognize the key red flags in an email or text message, you are no longer an easy target. You have the knowledge to spot a scam before it can cause any damage.

üöÄ What's Next?

Now that you know how to defend yourself from phishing, get ready to level up your skills. In our next lesson, we'll explore more deceptive tactics beyond just emails. We'll dive into pretexting and baiting‚Äîtechniques that often feel even more personal and are designed to make you drop your guard.

Resources & Next Steps

Read More: Real-world Examples

For real-world examples of phishing in the Philippines, check out these articles:

  • DICT Advisory: Syndicates use new SMS technique to scam e-wallet users
  • OneNews: Phishing scams target Philippine banks, e-wallets
Learn More: Impact & Trends

To see the impact of phishing in numbers, these articles offer insight into phishing trends and how vulnerable the Philippines has become:

  • The Varsitarian: Hacked here, hacked there: Investments needed to repel cyberattacks
  • Respicio & Co. Law Firm: Disputing and reporting phishing scams in the Philippines
üéØ Ready for the Next Challenge?

Next Lesson: You will now move on to Lesson 2.2: Pretexting & Baiting.

Lesson 2.2: Deception Beyond the Inbox

1. Beyond the Email

Deception Beyond the Inbox

Welcome!

You've learned how to spot a phishing scam in your email. But what happens when the scam isn't a link, but a phone call? This short video will introduce you to pretexting, a dangerous form of social engineering that uses a believable story to trick you.

Module 2 Lesson 2.2 Part A ‚Äî Beyond the Email
2. Pretexting

Pretexting (The Fabricated Story)

Welcome back!

This video will walk you through a step-by-step pretexting attack, so you know exactly how these fake stories are built and how you can spot them.

Module 2 Lesson 2.2 Part B ‚Äî Pretexting: The Fabricated Story
3. Baiting

Baiting

In this lesson, we're going to talk about a type of social engineering that's a little different. We call it baiting, and it's when a scammer uses a tempting offer to lure you into a trap. These attacks prey on our curiosity and our desire to get something for free.

So, what exactly is baiting? It's a form of social engineering where an attacker offers you something valuable or enticing‚Äîlike a free download, a gift card, or even a USB drive‚Äîto trick you into making a mistake. Once you take the bait, the scammer can get you to install malware on your device or reveal sensitive information.

Let's look at some common scenarios to see how baiting works in the real world.

Interactive Case Studies

Scenario 1: The "Study Cheat Sheet"

You're a student at MMDC working on a term paper, and you see an ad on a website for a "free study cheat sheet" that looks perfect for your topic. You click the link, and it asks you to download a file.

What was the bait? The bait was the "free study cheat sheet."
What was the risk? The risk is that the file could contain malware that infects your device or steals your personal information.
Scenario 2: The "Free Load Giveaway"

You see a post on Facebook for a "Free Load Giveaway" from a page that looks like it's from a local mobile network. All you have to do is click a link and enter your phone number to claim your prize.

What was the bait? The bait was the promise of "Free Load."
What was the risk? The risk is that the website is a fake. When you enter your phone number, the scammers can use it for a SIM swap attack or send you other malicious messages.
Scenario 3: The Lost USB Drive

You're in the school cafeteria, and you find a USB flash drive on the floor. It has a label on it that says, "Final Project - Do Not Erase." Naturally, your curiosity is piqued, and you plug it into your laptop to see if you can find the owner.

What was the bait? The bait was the USB drive itself, with the label "Final Project - Do Not Erase."
What was the risk? The risk is that the USB drive is infected with malware. Once you plug it in, it could automatically install a virus on your device and compromise your computer, even if you don't open any files.

Key Takeaway

You can see that the scams we've looked at rely on your emotions and curiosity. By learning to recognize these "lures" and always being cautious, you can protect your digital life from baiting attacks.

4. Conclusion: Pretexting & Baiting

Lesson Conclusion: Pretexting & Baiting

Great job on completing this lesson!

You've just leveled up your skills by learning how to identify two of the most clever social engineering attacks: pretexting and baiting.

Key Insights

Remember, these attacks are about more than just a suspicious email. They are about psychology and trust. Whether it's a scammer creating a fake story to get your information (pretexting) or a tempting offer that's too good to be true (baiting), the goal is to get you to willingly make a security mistake.

Your strongest defense is an informed and vigilant mind that questions every request, especially if it feels a little off.

What's Next?

Now that you've seen both digital and personal tricks, let's go even deeper. In our next lesson, we'll explore how social engineers operate in the physical world.

Resources & Next Steps

Read More

For a deeper look at pretexting, check out the article "What Is Pretexting?" from Proofpoint. For baiting, read the legal guide "Online Giveaway Prize Scam in the Philippines" which explains how baiting scams work in the local context.

Links:
https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/pretexting
https://www.respicio.ph/commentaries/online-giveaway-prize-scam-in-the-philippines
Watch Again

For a visual reminder of what these attacks look like, watch this short video on the "Psychology of social engineering".

Link:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BK8oJe8l2mo
Next Lesson

You will now move on to Lesson 2.3: Physical Social Engineering.

Lesson 2.3: Deception in the Real World

1. It's not just Online

Deception in the Real World

Welcome back!

So far, we've talked about digital scams like phishing and pretexting. But what if a scam doesn't happen on your phone or computer? This video will show you that social engineering isn't just an online threat‚Äîit's a real-world problem, too.

Get ready to learn how to defend your data in person.

Module 2 Lesson 2.3 Part A ‚Äî It's not just online
2. Physic Tactic

Common Physical Tactics

In our last video, we broke the myth that social engineering only happens online. Now, let's dive deeper into the tactics scammers use in the physical world. By understanding these tricks, you'll be much better at protecting yourself when you're out of the digital space and in the real world.

Tailgating: Don't Hold the Door

Tailgating is when a malicious person gains unauthorized physical access to a restricted area by following an authorized person. Scammers will use social engineering to get you to hold the door open for them. They might pretend to be a delivery person with their hands full, a new coworker, or a person who just forgot their ID.

This is a classic social engineering trick because it exploits our natural human tendency to be polite.
The risk? Once inside, they can easily access computers, get sensitive information, or even plant malware on an unlocked device.

Shoulder Surfing: Watch Your Back

Shoulder surfing is when an attacker secretly watches you to steal personal information, like your password or PIN. It often happens in crowded places where people are using their devices and are not paying close attention to their surroundings.

You are at risk of shoulder surfing when you're using your phone at an ATM, working on your laptop in a public caf√© or library, or using a shared computer in a school lab.
A scammer can get your information simply by looking over your shoulder. They can then use this to hack into your accounts and steal your identity.

Protecting Yourself in the Physical World

Now that you know what to look for, here are some simple, actionable habits to make yourself a Cyber Defender in the real world:

Don't Share Passwords or Leave Them Visible

Writing your passwords on a sticky note and leaving it on your monitor is a huge risk. Anyone can take a quick glance and get access to all your information. Even if you're alone, don't leave your passwords in a place where they can be easily seen.

Lock Screens When Stepping Away

Whether you're at a school computer or just getting a coffee in a library, always lock your screen when you step away. It only takes a second, but it can prevent an attacker from accessing your files and personal information.

Be Mindful of Surroundings When Typing PINs

When you're at an ATM, a payment terminal, or even just unlocking your phone, use your body or your hand to shield your screen and keypad from prying eyes.

Community Protection

These habits are not just for you; they also protect your friends and the entire MMDC community from a potential threat. Stay vigilant, stay safe!

3. Physic Security

Practical Security Awareness

You've learned that social engineering can happen in the real world, not just online. This infographic is your quick, at-a-glance guide to practicing good physical security habits. Keep it handy to protect yourself from scammers who rely on your lack of awareness.

This infographic is designed to be a quick, at-a-glance reminder of good physical security habits. It's about protecting your digital self even when you're in the real world.

"Always-On" Cyber Defender Habits

This is a plan for a single-page infographic you can create. It will focus on three key, easy-to-remember actions.

Ligtas sa Pisikal na Mundo (Safe in the Physical World)

A vertical, mobile-friendly design with three distinct sections

ü§´

Don't Share Secrets

Icon: A lock with a key, and a red "X" over a speech bubble.

Your passwords and PINs are for your eyes only. Avoid writing them down on sticky notes or saving them in plain sight. Even your best friend or family member should not know these.

üîí

Lock It Down

Icon: A laptop or phone with a visible lock screen icon.

Treat your device like your wallet. When you step away‚Äîeven for a minute‚Äîlock your screen. This prevents others from accessing your personal information or school accounts without your permission.

üëÄ

Be Aware

Icon: An eye looking around, with a pair of hands typing on a keypad.

When you're at an ATM, a school computer, or even just unlocking your phone, be mindful of your surroundings. Make sure no one is looking over your shoulder. This simple habit, called "shoulder surfing," can expose your sensitive information to attackers.

Quick Reference

These three simple habits form your "Always-On" cyber defense in the physical world. Practice them consistently, and you'll significantly reduce your risk of falling victim to real-world social engineering attacks.

4. Lesson Conclusion: Physical Security Awareness

Lesson Conclusion: Physical Security Awareness

Great job!

You've reached the end of Module 2. In this lesson, we proved that social engineering isn't just a digital threat; it's an attack that targets both your mind and your physical surroundings. By recognizing tactics like tailgating and shoulder surfing, you now have the skills to protect yourself in the real world.

Your journey to becoming a Cyber Defender has taken a big leap. You now understand how scammers use psychology and deception, and you can recognize and defend against the most common threats you'll encounter online and offline.

Resources & Next Steps

Read More

For a deeper dive into physical social engineering, check out these guides:

Fortinet: An article on "Tailgating Attack: Examples and Prevention" that provides more examples of how these attacks work.
https://www.fortinet.com/resources/cyberglossary/tailgating-attack
LifeLock: A comprehensive guide on "Shoulder Surfing" that explains how it works and gives tips on how to keep prying eyes away.
https://lifelock.norton.com/learn/identity-theft-resources/what-is-shoulder-surfing
Next Lesson

Before we move to the next module, it's time to test your knowledge and apply what you've learned.

You will now move on to the Module 2 Quiz, Reflection Activity, and Simulation Scenario.

Reflection

Module 2 Reflection: "Smarter Than the Scam"

Welcome to your reflection for Module 2! You've learned about some of the most clever social engineering tactics out there. Now, it's time to make this knowledge personal and turn it into your own defense.

Take a few minutes to think about the questions below and share your thoughts.

Reflection Prompts

Question 1

Think about the social engineering tactics you've learned in this module (phishing, pretexting, and baiting). Which one surprised you the most, and why?

Question 2

How can you apply this new awareness in your everyday student life, from online interactions to in-person situations?

Question 3

Have you ever encountered a situation that, in hindsight, might have been a form of baiting or pretexting? How would you respond to it differently now?

Share Your Thoughts

Use the space below to reflect on these questions and share your insights:

Simulation

üéÆ Simulation: Spot the Scams

Test your knowledge with real-world scenarios. Make the right choices to protect yourself and others!

How This Works

You'll face three different social engineering scenarios. For each one, choose the best response based on what you've learned. You'll get immediate feedback explaining why your choice was right or wrong, helping you learn from each decision.

1

The Phishing Email

üìß Email Details:

From: "MMDC Support" <suspicious@mmdc-fake.com>

Subject: URGENT: Your MMDC Email Will Be Suspended

Message: "Click here immediately to reset your password or your account will be suspended in 24 hours!"

üìß Suspicious Email Example

What action should you take?
Feedback:
2

The Pretexting Call

üìû Call Details:

A caller says they're from the Registrar's Office. They know your name and program, and they ask for your student ID to "fix a problem."

What should you do?
Feedback:
3

The Baiting Post

üì± Social Media Post:

On Facebook, you see a post claiming: "Win a FREE phone! Click here to join ‚Äî limited time only!"

üì± Suspicious Social Media Post

What action should you take?
Feedback:

Great job!

By making the right decisions, you avoided falling for phishing, pretexting, and baiting tactics. You're now better equipped to protect yourself and others from social engineering attacks!

Knowledge Check

Knowledge Check ‚Äî Module 2

Knowledge Check Rules

  • Unlimited attempts: You can take this knowledge check as many times as you need.
  • 5 questions per attempt. Passing score: 80%.
  • Question sets: Multiple question sets available for retakes.
  • Randomization: Questions are randomized for each attempt.

What You'll Be Tested On

This knowledge check will test your understanding of phishing, pretexting, baiting, and physical social engineering tactics. You'll need to identify different attack types, recognize red flags, and apply the defense strategies you've learned.

Topics Covered

  • Phishing attacks and red flags
  • Pretexting scenarios
  • Baiting tactics
  • Shoulder surfing
  • Tailgating
  • Physical security habits
Start Knowledge Check

You can retake this knowledge check as many times as needed to achieve a passing score.

References

modules.name: Fortifying Your Accounts
modules.description: Understanding password security and authentication methods
modules.content:
What to Expect

Welcome to Module 3! You've learned how to recognize social engineering tactics. Now, it's time to become a true Cyber Defender by building your defenses. This module will equip you with proactive digital defense strategies, from creating strong passwords to securing your social media profiles.

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Create a strong password and understand the value of password managers.
  • Manage your digital footprint and secure your social media profiles to prevent oversharing.
  • Verify online communications by checking links, URLs, and sender details before you click.

Module 3: Fortifying Your Accounts

Understanding password security and authentication methods

modules.name: Immediate Action After a Suspected Attack
modules.description: Learn immediate response steps when you suspect a social engineering attack
modules.content:
What to Expect

Welcome to Module 4! You've learned how to spot scams and protect your accounts. But what happens when an attack gets through? This module will be your most important guide yet. We'll teach you incident response and reporting protocols so you know exactly what to do when a security incident occurs.

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Follow an immediate action plan after a suspected attack to contain the damage.
  • Report a cyber incident to the right people at MMDC and external authorities.
  • Perform basic account recovery and secure your accounts with MFA.

Module 4: Immediate Action After a Suspected Attack

Learn immediate response steps when you suspect a social engineering attack

modules.name: The Evolving Threat Landscape
modules.description: Understanding emerging social engineering threats and future trends
modules.content:
What to Expect

Welcome to Module 5! You've mastered the basics of social engineering. But the threats are always evolving. This module will introduce you to advanced and emerging threats like deepfakes and AI-powered scams. The goal is to give you the habits and resources you need to stay ahead of the curve for life.

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Recognize advanced threats like AI-powered scams, deepfakes, and quishing.
  • Build proactive habits for continuous learning to stay one step ahead of new threats.
  • Embrace your role as a Cyber Defender who contributes to the community's digital safety.

Module 5: The Evolving Threat Landscape

Understanding emerging social engineering threats and future trends

modules.description: Comprehensive assessment covering all aspects of social engineering awareness and prevention
modules.content:
Module 6: Final Assessment

Comprehensive assessment covering all aspects of social engineering awareness and prevention

Final Assessment

Assessment Rules:
  • 25 Items with 80% passing rate
  • 3 attempts every 24hrs (in case of failing grade)
Start Final Assessment

Complete all requirements to unlock certificate generation

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the primary goal of social engineering attacks?
final_assessment_questions.option_a: To gain unauthorized access to computer systems
final_assessment_questions.option_b: To manipulate people into revealing confidential information
final_assessment_questions.option_c: To spread malware through email attachments
final_assessment_questions.option_d: To create fake websites for phishing
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Social engineering attacks primarily focus on manipulating human psychology to extract confidential information, rather than directly attacking technical systems.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a common social engineering technique?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: SQL Injection is a technical attack method, not a social engineering technique. Social engineering focuses on human manipulation.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What makes social engineering attacks particularly dangerous?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Social engineering is dangerous because it exploits human psychology, bypasses technical security, and is often difficult to detect.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which psychological principle is most commonly exploited in social engineering?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Social engineers exploit multiple psychological principles including authority, urgency, and trust to manipulate victims.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the first line of defense against social engineering?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Security awareness training is the first line of defense as it educates users to recognize and resist social engineering attempts.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is a red flag for social engineering?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: All these behaviors are red flags that may indicate a social engineering attempt.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What should you do if you suspect a social engineering attempt?
final_assessment_questions.option_b: Report it to your security team
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Suspected social engineering attempts should be reported to the security team immediately for investigation.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which factor makes social engineering attacks more likely to succeed?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: All these factors can make individuals more vulnerable to social engineering attacks.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the most common type of phishing attack?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Email phishing is the most common type, targeting large numbers of users with generic messages.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is a sign of a phishing email?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: All these characteristics are common indicators of phishing emails.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What should you do before clicking a link in an email?
final_assessment_questions.option_b: Hover over the link to check the URL
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Hovering over a link reveals the actual destination URL, helping identify suspicious links.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is spear phishing?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Spear phishing is a targeted attack against specific individuals, often using personal information.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a type of phishing?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Spamming is sending unsolicited bulk messages, not a type of phishing attack.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the best way to verify a suspicious email?
final_assessment_questions.option_b: Contact the sender through official channels
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Contact the sender through official, verified channels to confirm the legitimacy of the request.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What should you do if you receive a suspicious attachment?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Suspicious attachments should be deleted immediately without opening to prevent malware infection.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is a red flag in a phishing email?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: All these characteristics are common red flags in phishing emails.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the minimum recommended length for a strong password?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: A minimum of 12 characters is recommended for strong passwords to resist brute force attacks.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following makes a password stronger?
final_assessment_questions.option_c: Using a mix of characters, numbers, and symbols
final_assessment_questions.option_d: Using the same password for multiple accounts
final_assessment_questions.explanation: A strong password should include a mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and special characters.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)?
final_assessment_questions.option_b: Using two or more verification methods
final_assessment_questions.explanation: MFA requires two or more verification methods (something you know, have, or are) for authentication.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a good password practice?
final_assessment_questions.option_a: Using unique passwords for each account
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Passwords should never be shared, even with trusted colleagues, as this creates security risks.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a password manager?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Password managers help store, generate, and autofill strong passwords securely.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is a sign of a compromised account?
final_assessment_questions.option_b: Changes to account settings you didn't make
final_assessment_questions.explanation: All these signs may indicate that an account has been compromised.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What should you do if you suspect your account is compromised?
final_assessment_questions.option_b: Enable MFA if not already active
final_assessment_questions.explanation: If you suspect account compromise, change passwords, enable MFA, and check for unauthorized activity.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is the most secure authentication method?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Password + authenticator app provides the strongest security as authenticator apps are more secure than SMS.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the first step when you suspect a social engineering attack?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: The first step is to disconnect from the network to prevent further damage or data exfiltration.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Who should you notify first about a suspected attack?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: The IT Security team should be notified first as they are trained to handle security incidents.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What information should you document about the incident?
final_assessment_questions.option_a: Time and date of the incident
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Document all relevant details including time, date, what happened, and any communications for investigation.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What should you do with suspicious emails after reporting?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Keep suspicious emails as evidence for the security team's investigation.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following should you NOT do after a suspected attack?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: You should not continue using potentially compromised devices until they are checked by IT security.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the purpose of incident response procedures?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Incident response procedures help minimize damage, preserve evidence, and prevent future attacks.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: When should you change your passwords after a suspected attack?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Change passwords immediately after disconnecting to prevent further unauthorized access.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What should you do if you accidentally clicked a malicious link?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: If you clicked a malicious link, report it immediately and disconnect from the network to prevent further damage.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the main reason social engineering attacks are evolving?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Social engineering evolves due to both technological advances and increased security awareness, requiring attackers to adapt.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is an emerging social engineering threat?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: All these technologies represent emerging threats that can be used for social engineering attacks.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the best way to stay protected against evolving threats?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Protection against evolving threats requires continuous training, updates, and following security best practices.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is a future trend in social engineering?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Future trends include AI-powered attacks, social media exploitation, and targeting of Internet of Things devices.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What role does social media play in modern social engineering?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Social media provides attackers with personal information, mass communication tools, and ways to build trust.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: How can organizations prepare for future social engineering threats?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Organizations need comprehensive preparation including training, technology, and response planning.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: What is the importance of continuous learning in cybersecurity?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Continuous learning is essential because threats, attack methods, and security practices are constantly evolving.

final_assessment_questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key principle for future cybersecurity?
final_assessment_questions.explanation: Future cybersecurity relies on assuming breaches can happen, implementing zero trust, and using multiple defense layers.
